G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 19.proposition: The Premises are located in Worcester, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred in Worcester County; therefore, venue and jurisdiction are proper in the Worcester Division of the District Court Department.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a residential tenant is entitled to quiet enjoyment and to an apartment that complies with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and is fit for human habitation.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a residential tenant is entitled to quiet enjoyment and to an apartment that complies with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and is fit for human habitation.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a residential tenant is entitled to quiet enjoyment and to an apartment that complies with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and is fit for human habitation.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence/dissent that criticizes the majority’s broader implied warranty of habitability and would instead limit the landlord’s obligation to compliance with the State Sanitary Code. However, even this opinion recognizes that tenants are to “enjoy the rights which these various legal provisions have created for their benefit” and that renting a dwelling unit implies an agreement that it will comply with minimum statutory and code standards of fitness for human habitation. The majority opinion in Hemingway (not reproduced here) is well known for adopting an implied warranty of habitability in Massachusetts, so, taken as a whole, the case supports the proposition that Massachusetts residential tenants are entitled to quiet enjoyment and to an apartment that complies with the State Sanitary Code and is fit for human habitation, though the quoted excerpt alone focuses more narrowly on code compliance than on a free‑standing broad warranty.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

105 CMR 410.550.proposition: The presence of mouse droppings and rodent activity inside a dwelling unit constitutes a violation of the State Sanitary Code and a material interference with the quiet enjoyment of the premises.

Lipsitt v. Plowboy Realty Corp., 41 Mass.raw_text: Lipsitt v. Plowboy Realty Corp., 41 Mass. App. Ct. 238 (1996)
Lipsitt v. Plowboy Realty Corp., 41 Mass.proposition: The presence of mouse droppings and rodent activity inside a dwelling unit constitutes a violation of the State Sanitary Code and a material interference with the quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Lipsitt v. Plowboy Realty Corp., 41 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the effect of failing to issue a timely motor vehicle citation under G.L. c. 90C and whether the Commonwealth can use a private citizen complaint to circumvent that requirement. It does not address landlord-tenant law, State Sanitary Code violations, habitability, or quiet enjoyment, nor does it mention mouse droppings, rodent activity, or dwelling conditions. Therefore, it provides no authority for the stated proposition about sanitary code violations and interference with quiet enjoyment.
Lipsitt v. Plowboy Realty Corp., 41 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "The sole issue presented by this appeal is whether a private citizen’s complaint against the defendant for operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol was barred by a police officer's failure to issue the defendant a timely citation for this offense."

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to correct serious sanitary code violations and conditions affecting health or safety after notice can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses what conduct can violate the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and holds that at least negligent conduct by a landlord, including failure to repair known defects, can constitute such a breach. In doing so, it expressly cites prior cases where landlords’ failure to repair code-related defects of which they had notice (e.g., leaky roof, uninhabitable conditions) were deemed violations of § 14. That reasoning directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s failure to correct serious sanitary code or health/safety conditions after notice can breach quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to correct serious sanitary code violations and conditions affecting health or safety after notice can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that a landlord’s failure, after notice, to take reasonable steps to address conditions that seriously interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment. However, the court expressly limits the warranty of habitability to physical conditions and does not tie the quiet‑enjoyment analysis to sanitary code violations or to ‘sanitary code’ conditions as such. The decision is about criminal/drug activity in common areas and the landlord’s failure to act against nontenants, not about failure to correct serious sanitary code violations, so it does not directly support the specific sanitary‑code-based proposition stated.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment is the natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s acts and omissions, and Defendant knew or reasonably should have known that failure to address the rodent infestation adequately would substantially interfere with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court explains that, under the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment, liability arises when interference is the “natural and probable consequence” of the landlord’s conduct, not only when the landlord acts with specific intent. It holds that Gem’s failure to correct known, unsanitary flooding conditions—despite repeated complaints—made the resulting interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment foreseeable and thus actionable, and expressly ties § 14’s “actual and consequential damages” to all reasonably foreseeable harms. This reasoning supports the idea that a landlord who knows or should know that failing to address severe conditions (like infestations or flooding) will substantially interfere with a tenant’s enjoyment is liable for that interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute…. The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages… suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery.”

Thaxton v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals of Newb.raw_text: Thaxton v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals of Newbury, 59 Mass. App. Ct. 749, 754 (2003)
Thaxton v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals of Newb.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is incorporated into every residential tenancy agreement in Massachusetts, regardless of whether it is expressly stated in a written lease.
Thaxton v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals of Newb.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns contractual exculpatory and merger clauses in a real estate purchase and sale agreement and their effect on an intentional misrepresentation claim. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it discuss implied terms in residential tenancy agreements. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition about incorporation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment into every residential tenancy in Massachusetts.
Thaxton v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals of Newb.relevant_excerpt: We agree with the judge that the misrepresentation claim in this case was precluded by the merger and exculpatory clauses. While negotiations appear to have been rapid, the buyers were represented by an attorney who reserved the right to consult further with the buyers before finalizing the agreement. The clause stating that the buyers relied completely on the home inspector was customized to this contract. Both it and the merger clause were reviewed by the buyers’ attorney and survived his revisions and additions constituting part of the signed contract.

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 747–48 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Defendant’s failure to abate the infestation and to remedy the unsanitary condition, after notice and over an extended period, constitutes an “indirect interference” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion rejects, rather than accepts, a quiet-enjoyment claim on facts involving alleged code violations including ant infestation and other unsanitary-type issues. The court states that quiet enjoyment protects against “serious interference” and then holds there was no evidence of interference because the landlord acted promptly to remedy the conditions. It does not hold that a landlord’s failure to abate an infestation over time constitutes “indirect interference” under G.L. c. 186, § 14; instead it finds no breach on these facts.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment… We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy… Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions… The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 9.proposition: To the extent applicable, Plaintiff also relies on the remedial principles of G.L. c. 93A, §§ 2, 9 (unfair or deceptive acts or practices in trade or commerce), and G.L. c. 239, § 8A (defenses and counterclaims in summary process based on breach of quiet enjoyment and sanitary code violations), not as separate causes of action in this complaint, but as persuasive authorities recognizing the seriousness of sanitary code violations and quiet enjoyment breaches in Massachusetts residential tenancies.

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: To the extent applicable, Plaintiff also relies on the remedial principles of G.L. c. 93A, §§ 2, 9 (unfair or deceptive acts or practices in trade or commerce), and G.L. c. 239, § 8A (defenses and counterclaims in summary process based on breach of quiet enjoyment and sanitary code violations), not as separate causes of action in this complaint, but as persuasive authorities recognizing the seriousness of sanitary code violations and quiet enjoyment breaches in Massachusetts residential tenancies.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies and interprets both G.L. c. 93A, § 9 in the residential landlord‑tenant context and recognizes serious sanitary code and habitability violations, and it arises out of a summary process action where the tenant asserted counterclaims similar to those permitted by G.L. c. 239, § 8A (breach of warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment based on code violations). While the case is not a direct construction of § 8A itself, it treats these statutory and common‑law rights as significant remedial tools for tenants and underscores the seriousness of sanitary code and quiet enjoyment breaches in Massachusetts residential tenancies, matching the limited, “persuasive authority” use described in the proposition.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “After her landlord… commenced a summary process action… for nonpayment of rent, the defendant… filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14…; … and (6) violations of G.L. c. 93A.… [T]he judge found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A (for the intentional infliction of emotional distress and violation of the warranty of habitability)…. We now affirm.”

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.proposition: To the extent applicable, Plaintiff also relies on the remedial principles of G.L. c. 93A, §§ 2, 9 (unfair or deceptive acts or practices in trade or commerce), and G.L. c. 239, § 8A (defenses and counterclaims in summary process based on breach of quiet enjoyment and sanitary code violations), not as separate causes of action in this complaint, but as persuasive authorities recognizing the seriousness of sanitary code violations and quiet enjoyment breaches in Massachusetts residential tenancies.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.support_reasoning: The case is a landlord-tenant dispute where the tenant prevailed on counterclaims for negligence, breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and G.L. c. 186, § 14 (quiet enjoyment), and the court affirmed damages and multiple damages under G.L. c. 93A. In doing so, the Appeals Court expressly ties sanitary code violations, inadequate security (door), flooding, and ongoing leaks/roaches to violations of c. 93A and to substantial rent abatements and other damages, thereby recognizing the seriousness of sanitary code and quiet enjoyment breaches in residential tenancies. The opinion does not discuss G.L. c. 239, § 8A expressly, but it clearly uses c. 93A and related landlord-tenant doctrines as remedial frameworks in this context, which is consistent with citing those statutes as persuasive remedial authorities rather than separate causes of action.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that at the inception of LeClair’s tenancy there were a number of violations of the State Sanitary Code and that these problems had caused the prior tenant to vacate the premises after living there a few months. He also found that the landlord was repeatedly notified of the ongoing leaks and other problems on several occasions, and that, despite these complaints, the leakage and the roach problem remained uncorrected through April, 1982…. Damages were awarded under G. L. c. 93A, the judge concluding that his findings of negligence and of breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and of G. L. c. 186, § 14, ‘also constitute a violation of G. L. c. 93A.’
